Chickens, part 2

Chipping away at the coop this winter, one month in.

  • Written: Feb 28, 2024

Chipping away at the coop, one month in.

More wood

The cedar was great, but it felt thick at 1"-1.5" wide and might make the chickshaw heavy to do the whole thing from it.

I considered cutting it down to have 1/2" boards for the sides and bottom. ‚ÄúResawing‚Äù it, they call it. As in, sawing-again, after the sawmill did its job.

I inherited a band saw a few years ago but I feel inept when behind it. Even if i wasn‚Äôt, resawing like this is slow and uneven. It can also be done with a table saw, which I don‚Äôt have yet, and with a circular or hand saw, but neither of those looked like fun.

Then I saw a craigslist post labeled ‚ÄúRough cut hemlock framing.‚Äù He had 8" x 1" boards available. I asked if he‚Äôd be willing to cut them down to 1/2" and he agreed!

He didn‚Äôt even charge for the extra cuts so in total they came out to 50 cents per board foot. And were sourced from local trees, so that was pretty cool.

Building

The pieces were gigantic at 16‚Äô for my little SUV, but I got them home without breaking the roof or having them fly off. After arranging them by my chop saw in my 17‚Äô garage, I cut them down.

I overestimated on both the cedar and hemlock, but this building stuff is fun. I‚Äôm happy to have extra.

The nest door works. I‚Äôm a carpenter!

Thought there‚Äôd be more to it. shrug

To do

  • Get waterproof, cleanable flooring. I probably don't need this but it's been recommended, as this floor won't easily come out.
  • Figure roofing. I didn't think this one through. with the box being 4' x 4', I thought one 8' x 4' metal roofing panel would do, but nope. This didn't account for overlapping the panels and for overhang we'll want on each side.
  • Get hardware cloth
